channel.title: Creating settings dialogs in java
channel.description: Hi, I am creating a settings dialog box in my new server. I an trying to create a settings typically seen in programs which has tabs and sections. I can get the tabs and sections but when I try to put the various components in, they won't go the way I want them to. For example, I want a label before a text box, but when I add the components for the next line down, they end up next to the ones line above (ie. The text box on the top line). I cannot find the right layout for what I'm trying to do. The only way that I've found of doing it is using absolute positioning to get the right components on the right lines. Is there another way, or am I stuck with absolute positioning? By the way, I'm using swing components, not the awt ones...

[/quote]i was hoping that someone would have bought the domain and filled it with viruses

making a gui hardly requires any knowledge, drag and drop using a wysiwyg editor

Where can I get an editor like that for java?[/quote]
here

item.title: Creating settings dialogs in java
item.dc:creator: @ada ada
item.description:
@ada wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:4, topic:175254”]http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/swing/BoxLayout.html

BoxLayout gives you full power over stacking components on top of each other or placing them next to each other. You can easily use BoxLayout to stack two panels on top of each other which both use BoxLayout to place a label before a text field.

Oh, and, if you do not want to use swing, look into using http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/awt/BorderLayout.html.[/quote]
Thanks for that! At least someone’s willing to help me…

Read full topic

item.title: Creating settings dialogs in java
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/swing/BoxLayout.html

BoxLayout gives you full power over stacking components on top of each other or placing them next to each other. You can easily use BoxLayout to stack two panels on top of each other which both use BoxLayout to place a label before a text field.

Oh, and, if you do not want to use swing, look into using http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/awt/BorderLayout.html.

Read full topic
